G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and analogous provisions such as G.L. c. 209C, § 20, the Probate and Family Court may modify a prior judgment concerning custody or parenting time upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and a determination that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and analogous provisions such as G.L. c. 209C, § 20, the Probate and Family Court may modify a prior judgment concerning custody or parenting time upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and a determination that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: To the extent the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act (UCCJEA), G.L. c. 209B, applies, this Court is the child’s “home state” court and retains exclusive, continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting time matters concerning the minor child.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: In determining best interests, the Court considers the totality of the circumstances, including the child’s age, developmental needs, relationship with each parent, the stability of each home, and the practical effects of any schedule on the child’s routine, schooling, and emotional well‑being.

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long held that to modify a custody or parenting‑time order, a party must show: (1) a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child since the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns a removal request (relocation) and a child support modification; it does not articulate or apply the general two‑part standard for modifying custody or parenting‑time orders. The only explicit reference to a ‘material and substantial change of circumstances’ appears in the child support context, tied to G.L. c. 208, § 28, not to custody or parenting time. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that a party must show a material and substantial change plus best interests to modify a custody/parenting‑time order.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.relevant_excerpt: “In support of his complaint for modification, the father alleged as a material and substantial change of circumstances the mother’s remarriage. At the time of the modification trial, the judge found that the father’s income had modestly increased, and that the mother’s income remained at zero.”

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long held that to modify a custody or parenting‑time order, a party must show: (1) a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child since the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses standards for initial custody determinations, visitation, abuse prevention orders, and removal, but it does not address the standard for *modification* of an existing custody or parenting‑time order. There is no articulation of a two‑part “material and substantial change plus best interests” test, nor any discussion of what must be shown to modify prior custody/parenting orders. Accordingly, this case does not provide authority for the specific modification standard described in the proposition.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In Massachusetts the focus in a custody dispute between parents is not on their personal rights but on the welfare of the child.… ‘[I]n deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.’ … In exercising discretion, the judge is authorized ‘to consider the widest range of permissible evidence.’” (Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. at 246)

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long held that to modify a custody or parenting‑time order, a party must show: (1) a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child since the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns standards for making an initial custody determination in a divorce judgment and emphasizes that child custody must be based on the best interests/welfare of the child. It does not address modification of an existing custody or parenting‑time order, nor does it mention any requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances since a prior judgment. Thus it cannot be cited as authority for the two‑part modification standard described in the proposition.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long held that to modify a custody or parenting‑time order, a party must show: (1) a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child since the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standards for an initial custody determination in a divorce (best interests of the child and equal parental rights), not the standard for later modification of an existing custody or parenting‑time order. It nowhere states that a party must show a material and substantial change in circumstances plus that modification is necessary to serve the child’s best interests, which is the two‑part modification standard described in the proposition. Thus it does not provide authority for the claimed rule about modification of custody or parenting time.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long held that to modify a custody or parenting‑time order, a party must show: (1) a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child since the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case discusses the standard for initial custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) (“best interests of the child”) and expressly declines to apply or analyze the “substantial change in circumstances” standard under G.L. c. 209C, § 20. While it acknowledges that § 20 contains such a standard, it does so only in passing and refuses to address its application, holding the issue waived. Therefore, the opinion does not establish or affirm the two‑part standard for modifying existing custody or parenting‑time orders; it treats this matter as an initial custody determination, not a modification proceeding.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long held that to modify a custody or parenting‑time order, a party must show: (1) a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child since the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is a direct‑review custody appeal dealing with the adequacy of findings about domestic violence, not a post‑judgment modification proceeding. Nowhere does the court discuss the standard for modifying an existing custody or parenting‑time order, nor does it refer to a requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances. The case therefore cannot be cited as authority for the two‑part modification standard described in the proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

Kendall v. Kendall, 426 Mass. 238 (1997).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long held that to modify a custody or parenting‑time order, a party must show: (1) a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child since the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child.
Kendall v. Kendall, 426 Mass. 238 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion in Kendall v. Kendall is about restrictions on a parent’s religious upbringing of children and the constitutional standard of “substantial harm” needed to limit religious expression. It does not concern modification of an existing custody or parenting‑time order based on a material and substantial change in circumstances. The only custody discussion is whether awarding joint legal custody in the original divorce judgment was an abuse of discretion, not what standard governs modification of custody judgments over time.
Kendall v. Kendall, 426 Mass. 238 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “5. Joint custody. The plaintiff argues on cross appeal that it was an abuse of discretion to award joint legal custody to the parties. The determination of custody rests within the discretion of the judge. Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409 (1976). The material facts found and reported must support the judge’s action in awarding joint legal custody to the parties. Id.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long held that to modify a custody or parenting‑time order, a party must show: (1) a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child since the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion directly cites and applies G. L. c. 208, § 28, stating that a Probate Court may modify a prior custody judgment upon finding (1) a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties and (2) that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the children. The court then evaluates whether such a material and substantial change occurred and whether the custody modification serves the children’s best interests, aligning squarely with the proposition stated.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ See Hartog v. Hartog, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 124, 128 (1989), and cases cited.”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long held that to modify a custody or parenting‑time order, a party must show: (1) a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child since the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an initial custody petition and affirmance of a custody/visitation decree, not a later motion to modify an existing final custody or parenting‑time order. The court discusses the best‑interests standard and notes that custody orders may be subject to future modification, but it does not articulate or apply the two‑part ‘material and substantial change in circumstances plus best interests’ test for modification. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.” … “We hold that the judge correctly applied these principles in deciding this case… As to the circumstances in which orders for the custody of minor children may be subject to future modification by the court see G. L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30, Palmer v. Palmer, 357 Mass. 764 (1970), and Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 550 (1930).”

Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545 (1930).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long held that to modify a custody or parenting‑time order, a party must show: (1) a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child since the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child.
Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545 (1930).support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes that custody orders in divorce are interlocutory and may be modified upon "good cause shown," and it emphasizes that the governing principle is the welfare of the child. However, it does not articulate a requirement that the moving party demonstrate a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment as a distinct prerequisite to modification. The modern two‑part test in the proposition (material change plus best interests) is not expressly stated or clearly adopted in this case, so the citation somewhat overstates what Hersey holds.
Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545 (1930).relevant_excerpt: "Orders as to custody of children in the cases arising under these sections are not final in the sense that a judgment in a proceeding at law or a final decree in a suit in equity is final and not subject to subsequent change by the court. They are in their nature interlocutory and subject to modification at any future time during the lives of the parents and the minority of the children upon good cause shown. ... The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child."

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 226\u20.proposition: The Court also gives appropriate weight to the child’s reasonable preferences, particularly when the child is of sufficient age and maturity to express meaningful views about parenting time, though such preferences are not controlling.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 226\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses many best‑interests factors (stability, sibling relationships, comparative abilities of caretakers, deference to trial judge, etc.), but it does not address, even generally, the role of the child’s own stated preferences or wishes about placement or parenting time. Hugo was four years old and there is no mention of eliciting or weighing his views. Thus, the case cannot be cited for the principle that the court gives appropriate but non‑controlling weight to a child’s reasonable preferences.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 226\u20.relevant_excerpt: Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The “best interests of a child” is a question that presents the trial judge “with a classic example of a discretionary decision.” … [M]uch must be left to the trial judge’s experience and judgment.

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766 (.proposition: The Court also gives appropriate weight to the child’s reasonable preferences, particularly when the child is of sufficient age and maturity to express meaningful views about parenting time, though such preferences are not controlling.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766 (.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the role of a child’s preferences in custody determinations, stating that such preferences—especially for a mature child—may be considered and even given great weight, but are not controlling. The court criticizes the trial judge for possibly giving the child’s wishes inappropriate weight and reiterates that the controlling question remains the child’s welfare, not the child’s preference alone. This aligns closely with the proposition about giving appropriate, but not determinative, weight to a mature child’s reasonable preferences regarding parenting time or custody.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766 (.relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s findings and some of the observations included in his conclusions suggest that he may have given inappropriate weight to the child’s wishes. … ‘[I]t has long been the law of Massachusetts that the preferences of children of sufficient maturity may be considered’ and even given ‘great weight.’ … The wishes of an unusually bright ten year old child are appropriately considered. However, they are not controlling. The controlling question is whether the welfare of this child would be seriously endangered if custody is not transferred from the mother.”

Adoption of Paula, 420 Mass. 716, 731\u2.proposition: Where, as here, a prior limitation on overnight contact was based in significant part on a parent’s then‑inadequate housing or physical circumstances, the later acquisition of appropriate, stable housing suitable for overnights may constitute a material and substantial change, permitting expansion of parenting time.
Adoption of Paula, 420 Mass. 716, 731\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion is an adoption/termination-of-parental-rights case that focuses on parental unfitness, evidentiary issues, and procedural matters. It does not discuss parenting time, visitation, or modification standards based on changes in housing or physical circumstances. Nothing in the decision addresses overnight contact limitations or how later acquisition of suitable housing could constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances, so it cannot be authority for the proposition stated.
Adoption of Paula, 420 Mass. 716, 731\u2.relevant_excerpt:
We take this opportunity, however, to comment on an issue raised by the father regarding the right of a parent in a care and protection proceeding to take the deposition of a person likely to be called as a witness at trial.

... A judge considering a petition brought by the department pursuant to G. L. c. 210, § 3, to dispense with parental consent to adoption is required to evaluate whether the parent contesting the petition is fit to provide for the welfare and the best interests of the child whose adoption is being considered.

Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.raw_text: Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 186, 193–194 (2016)
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.proposition: Even where parents generally cooperate or agree that a change is needed, the Court must still determine the specific schedule that best serves the child’s interests, but their agreement is highly relevant to the feasibility and likely success of a modified parenting plan.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.case_name: N-Tek Construction Services, Inc. v. Hartford Fire Insurance Co.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns notice requirements under a public construction payment bond statute (G. L. c. 149, § 29) and does not address parenting plans, custody, or modification of parenting schedules. Nothing in the holding or reasoning discusses parental cooperation, agreements about changing a parenting plan, or how such agreements factor into a court’s best-interests analysis. The case is therefore inapposite to the claimed family-law proposition.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: A person who has furnished labor or materials for public works and who has not been fully paid has a right under § 29 to seek recovery under the bond of the general contractor in satisfaction of amounts justly due. Section 29 attaches three conditions to this right. A claimant must be eligible to claim protection under § 29; give written notice to the general contractor of its claim; and commence an action in Superior Court within the time limitations established by the statute.
